Journal.Title: Journal of geophysical research. Atmospheres : JGR

Article.ArticleTitle: How have Divergent Global Emission Trends Influenced Long-range Transported Ozone to North America?

AbstractText: Several locations across the United States in non-compliance with the national standard for ground-level ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) are thought to have sizeable influences from distant extra-regional emission sources or natural stratospheric O<sub>3</sub>, which complicates design of local emission control measures. To quantify the amount of long-range transported O<sub>3</sub> (LRT O<sub>3</sub>), its origin, and change over time, we conduct and analyze detailed sensitivity calculations characterizing the response of O<sub>3</sub> to emissions from different source regions across the Northern Hemisphere in conjunction with multi-decadal simulations of tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> distributions and changes. Model calculations show that the amount of O<sub>3</sub> at any location attributable to sources outside North America varies both spatially and seasonally. On a seasonal-mean basis, during 1990-2010, LRT O<sub>3</sub> attributable to international sources steadily increased by 0.06-0.2 ppb yr<sup>-1</sup> at locations across the United States and arose from superposition of unequal and contrasting trends in individual source-region contributions, which help inform attribution of the trend evident in O<sub>3</sub> measurements. Contributions of emissions from Europe steadily declined through 2010, while those from Asian emissions increased and remained dominant. Steadily rising NO<sub>x</sub> emissions from international shipping resulted in increasing contributions to LRT O<sub>3</sub>, comparable to those from Asian emissions in recent years. Central American emissions contribute a significant fraction of LRT O<sub>3</sub> in southwestern United States. In addition to the LRT O<sub>3</sub> attributable to emissions outside of North America, background O<sub>3</sub> across the continental United States is comprised of a sizeable and spatially variable fraction that is of stratospheric origin (29-78%).
